   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who was transferred from [**Hospital1 **] to [**Hospital1 1**] with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating [**Hospital1 5286**],
   renal failure and altered mental status.
   #) Respiratory failure: Initial CXR and CT evidence of LLL
   consolidation, consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out GBS.
   Patient has been treated with penicillin G and clinda, and his
   pneumonia is improving on imaging. TTE showed normal EF, r/o CHF.
   Patient's smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Pt has HSV
   infection from two sources (nasopharynx and lip). This respiratory
   failure could potentially be secondary to generalized HSV infection,
   the HSV DFA and culture from mini-BAL are pending. The current barriers
   to extubation include altered mental status, severe metabolic acidosis,
   bilateral pleural effusion, and pneumonia which is improving.
   - on  AC currently, RR increased from 18 to 22 in an attempt to blow
   off CO2 when he is being given bicarb
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours (day1:
   [**8-6**]) to inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per ID this
   presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - continue doxy (day1: [**8-8**]);  if no RMSF,  will d/c doxy
   - given bicarb (150meq in 1000cc D5W) x1 today, re-check lytes in the
   pm and see if metabolic acidosis improves. If it did, can give another
   dose of bicarb
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u on ID recs
   .
   #) sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given his
   pneumonia.   Generalized HSV infection is another possibility but is
   less likely.  [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim was normal. Other source of infection includes
   GI but no evidence of GI infection at this time, no diarrhea noted. KUB
   on [**8-3**] showed small amount of pericholecystic fluid, but no
   cholecystitis was seen. However, given pt is intermittently
   hypotensive, it is possible that pt has some degree of bowel ischemia
   leading to bacteremia. UA was negative. Pt has a coccyx ulcer but the
   wound does not appear infected. Blood culture has been negative, and
   TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of sinusitis, so wouldn
   get at CT sinus at this point.
   - treat underlying PNA.  continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8
   hours (the drug of choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to
   inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures and other infectious panel: f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma
   phagocytophilum (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Babesia
   Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella zoster
   Antibody, IgM
   - will aggressively resuscitate with LR.  wean down pressors as pt has
   evidence of digital ischemia now. Goal MAP 55 (given his very low
   diastolic), although it would still be ideal to get his MAP to 65 to
   adequately perfuse his brain for improvement in mental status
   - hope to decrease his pressor requirements when metabolic acidosis
   improves on bicarb
   - goal I/O at least 1 liter positive as pt has lots of insensible fluid
   loss from skin
   - goal UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and ScvO2 >70%
   - follow lactate
   - culture if spikes
   - continue wound care for coccyx ulcer
   - would consider CT abdomen if pt does not improve
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis: pt continues to have an anion gap, likely due to
   renal failure and lactic acidosis. Non-anion gap acidosis significantly
   improved.
   - give bicarb today, increase RR from 18 to 22  when giving bicarb
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   - continue to follow renal function and lactate levels
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr slowly improving.   Most likely [**12-21**] ATN from
   hypotension from sepsis.
   - support blood pressure for adequate perfusion of kidneys
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin [**Last Name (LF) 5286**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**]
   aggressively resuscitate with LR
   - renally dose medications
   .
   #) [**First Name3 (LF) **]: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin [**First Name3 (LF) 5286**]. Per derm, this is either GBS,
   generalized pustulosis (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of
   psoriasis. derm path from [**Hospital1 **]: c/w hypersensitivity reaction:
   consider drug-induced or viral etiology.  Paraneoplastic syndrome
   cannot be exluded. Less likely HSV [**Hospital1 5286**], but it it not completely
   impossible.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir per ID
   - continue triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin [**Hospital1 5286**]
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Exam revealed some stereotypical decorticate
   reflexes. Unclear whether it is HSV encephalitis. Also likely [**12-21**]
   sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   - CT head x2 were negative for any intracranial process.
   - hold off on MRI for now
   - consider LP after clarification of goals of care
   - adequate blood pressure control for better perfusion of brain (goal
   MAP 65 but it may not be a realistic goal as the diastolic pressure has
   been very low). For now, maintain goal MAP at least 55 with IVF first,
   if still low then up the pressors. Hoping bicarb will help with
   acidosis and decrease pressor requirements and help with blood
   pressure.
   - continue thiamine
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 1u pRBC on [**8-13**]. On admission Hct was
   31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic
   disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Fe studies revealed
   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No
   evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal
   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct 21. Transfuse if hct <21
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient initially had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p
   free water flushes q6h which was discontinued
   - continue to monitor
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 48 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - now that levophed restarted, need to monitor
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - update family
   - will need to watch this weekend, and see if he improves
   - will need to discuss tracheostomy early next week, patient will have
   been intubated for 2 weeks on Monday

Summary:

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was diagnosed with pneumonia, HSV infection, and sepsis. He is currently being treated with antibiotics, antivirals, and bicarbonate to manage his acidosis. He has a history of smoking, which puts him at risk for COPD.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to his pneumonia, and he may require more aggressive ventilation or even tracheostomy.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may lead to further organ dysfunction, including renal failure, and may require more aggressive treatment, including vasopressors and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may worsen if his bicarbonate levels are not monitored and adjusted accordingly.
4. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure may progress if his blood pressure is not adequately controlled, and he may require more aggressive diuresis or even dialysis.
5. Skin complications: The patient's diffuse desquamating rash may worsen if his skin is not properly cared for, and he may be at risk for skin infections or necrosis.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status may worsen if his brain perfusion is not adequately maintained, and he may be at risk for further neurological decline.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if his blood loss is not adequately managed, and he may require further transfusions.
8. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may worsen if his free water intake is not monitored and adjusted accordingly.
9. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of SVT and Afib with RVR may increase his risk of cardiac complications, including arrhythmias and cardiomyopathy.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's current plan is to continue antibiotics and antivirals for his pneumonia and HSV infection, and to monitor his acidosis and renal function closely. He will also require ongoing respiratory support, including ventilation and oxygen therapy. His skin will need to be closely monitored for signs of infection or necrosis, and his neurological status will need to be regularly assessed for signs of further decline. His anemia and hyponatremia will need to be monitored and managed accordingly. Finally, his cardiac status will need to be closely monitored for signs of arrhythmias or cardiomyopathy.

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory failure. He was hospitalized for probable drug rash and developed acute respiratory failure/sepsis, GBS sepsis, and HSV infection. The patient has multiorgan failure, including respiratory failure, renal failure, shock, and acidosis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory support: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 40% and PEEP of 5 cmH2O. His SpO2 is 99%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's MAP is 94 mmHg, and he is pressor-dependent on vasopressin and levophed.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 4,772 mL of IV fluids and has a total output of 1,125 mL.
* Laboratory results: The patient's WBC count is 15.0, Hct is 21.9, and Plt is 130. His Cr is 2.7, and his TCO2 is 15.
* Physical examination: The patient's general appearance is normal, with no acute distress. His respiratory examination is significant for diminished breath sounds.

The patient's potential medical complications are:

1. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is 130, which is within the normal range.
2. Altered mental status: The patient is sedated and has minimal responsiveness with occasional grimacing and no corneal reflexes.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure secondary to pneumonia with left lower lobe involvement.
4. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis secondary to GBS sepsis, HSV infection, and possible tick-borne illness.
5. Renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure with a Cr of 2.7.
6. Shock: The patient has shock secondary to sepsis and is pressor-dependent on vasopressin and levophed.
7. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is 136 mmol/L.
8. Impaired skin integrity: The patient has a diffuse rash.

The patient's plan of care is as follows:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ventilation settings will be adjusted to decrease his RR to 14 and Vt to 500.
2. Sepsis: The patient will continue to receive broad-spectrum antibiotics, including PCN G and Clindamycine, for GBS sepsis and Acyclovir for HSV infection.
3. Renal failure: The patient's volume status will be enhanced to improve his renal function.
4. Altered mental status: The patient's sedation will be minimized, and he will be monitored for any changes in his neuro status.
5. Shock: The patient will be maintained on pressors to achieve a MAP of >55 mmHg.

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and his disposition is ICU care.

   - continue day 8 of doxy for possible tick borne illness (day1: [**8-8**]);
   if no RMSF,  will d/c doxy

   - f/u cultures
   - f/u on ID recs

   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection

   Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella zoster
   Antibody, IgM

   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No

t have another episode during the past 48 hours. pt was

   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability

   .

   - continue to monitor on tele

   .

   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .

   - update family

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, who was transferred to the ICU with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating rash, GBS pneumonia, and sepsis. He is currently intubated and on pressors, with a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute. His vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.7°C (98°F)
* Heart rate: 92 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 118/33 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 26 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 94%
* Central venous pressure: 8 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 14.8 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 23.8%
* Platelet count: 113 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 2.4 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 17 mmol/L
* Glucose: 141 mg/dL
* Sodium: 135 mmol/L
* Potassium: 4.0 mmol/L
* Chloride: 105 mmol/L
* Bicarbonate: 21.3 mmol/L

The patient's medical conditions include:

* GBS pneumonia
* Sepsis
* Respiratory failure
* Metabolic acidosis
* Renal failure
* Anemia
* Hyponatremia
* SVT (supraventricular tachycardia)
* Afib with RVR (atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response)
* Transaminitis
* Hypothyroidism

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Antibiotics for GBS pneumonia and sepsis
* Antiviral therapy for HSV infection
* Supportive care for respiratory failure and metabolic acidosis
* Renal replacement therapy for renal failure
* Blood transfusions for anemia
* Medication adjustments for SVT and Afib
* Monitoring for potential complications such as pulmonary edema, cardiac arrhythmias, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Pulmonary edema due to fluid overload
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to electrolyte imbalances or medication interactions
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to anticoagulant therapy or stress ulcer disease
* Infection due to indwelling lines or devices
* Renal failure progression
* Respiratory failure progression
* Cardiac failure progression
* Neurological complications due to HSV encephalitis or sepsis

The patient's goals of care are to improve his respiratory status, manage his sepsis and metabolic acidosis, and prevent further complications. His family has requested a family meeting to discuss his care and potential withdrawal of life-sustaining therapies.

   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who was transferred from [**Hospital1 **] to [**Hospital1 1**] with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating [**Hospital1 5286**],
   found to have GBS pneumonia and sepsis and multiorgan failure (renal
   failure/resp failure/shock/acidosis).
   #) Respiratory failure:  In the context of GBS pneumonia.  Patient has
   been treated with penicillin G and clinda, and his pneumonia is
   improving on imaging.  This respiratory failure could potentially be
   secondary to generalized HSV infection, the HSV DFA and culture from
   mini-BAL are pending. The current barriers to extubation include
   altered mental status, severe metabolic acidosis, bilateral pleural
   effusion, and pneumonia which is improving.  TTE showed normal EF, r/o
   CHF. Patient's smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Pt has HSV
   infection from two sources (nasopharynx and lip).
   - on  AC currently, RR increased from 18 to 22 in an attempt to blow
   off CO2 when he is being given bicarb
   - continue day 10 of penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the
   drug of choice for GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours
   (day1: [**8-6**]) to inhibit toxin production
   - continue day 12 of acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per
   ID this presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - continue day 8 of doxy for possible tick borne illness (day1: [**8-8**]);
   if no RMSF,  will d/c doxy
   - given bicarb (150meq in 1000cc D5W) x1 today, re-check lytes in the
   pm and see if metabolic acidosis improves. If it did, can give another
   dose of bicarb
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u on ID recs
   .
   #) sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given his
   pneumonia.   Generalized HSV infection is another possibility but is
   less likely.  [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim was normal.  Continues to remain remain
   pressors-dependent on vasopressin and levophed.  UA was negative. Blood
   culture has been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No
   evidence of sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - treat underlying PNA.  continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8
   hours (the drug of choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to
   inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures and other infectious panel: f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma
   phagocytophilum (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Babesia
   Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella zoster
   Antibody, IgM
   - wean down pressors as pt has evidence of digital ischemia now. Goal
   MAP 55 (given his very low diastolic), although it would still be ideal
   to get his MAP to 55 to adequately perfuse his brain for improvement in
   mental status
   - with ongoing pleural effusions and nl CVP, would attempt to maintain
   MAP with pressors rather than IVF
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis: pt continues to have an anion gap, likely due to
   renal failure and lactic acidosis. Non-anion gap acidosis significantly
   improved.
   - give bicarb today, increase RR from 18 to 22  when giving bicarb
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr slowly improving.   Most likely [**12-21**] ATN from
   hypotension from sepsis.
   - support blood pressure for adequate perfusion of kidneys
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin [**Last Name (LF) 5286**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**]
   aggressively resuscitate with LR
   - renally dose medications
   .
   #) [**First Name3 (LF) **]: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin [**First Name3 (LF) 5286**]. Per derm, this is either GBS,
   generalized pustulosis (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of
   psoriasis. derm path from [**Hospital1 **]: c/w hypersensitivity reaction:
   consider drug-induced or viral etiology.  Paraneoplastic syndrome
   cannot be exluded. Less likely HSV [**Hospital1 5286**], but it it not completely
   impossible.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir per ID
   - continue triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin [**Hospital1 5286**]
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Exam revealed some stereotypical decorticate
   reflexes. Unclear whether it is HSV encephalitis. Also likely [**12-21**]
   sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   - CT head x2 were negative for any intracranial process.
   - hold off on MRI for now
   - consider LP after clarification of goals of care
   - adequate blood pressure control for better perfusion of brain (goal
   MAP 65 but it may not be a realistic goal as the diastolic pressure has
   been very low). For now, maintain goal MAP at least 55 with IVF first,
   if still low then up the pressors. Hoping bicarb will help with
   acidosis and decrease pressor requirements and help with blood
   pressure.
   - continue thiamine
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 1u pRBC on [**8-13**]. On admission Hct was
   31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic
   disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Fe studies revealed
   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No
   evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal
   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct 21. Transfuse if hct <21
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient initially had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p
   free water flushes q6h which was discontinued
   - continue to monitor
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 48 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - now that levophed restarted, need to monitor
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - update family
   - will need to watch this weekend, and see if he improves
   - will need to discuss tracheostomy early next week, patient will have
   been intubated for 2 weeks on Monday

t have another episode during the past 48 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - now that levophed restarted, need to monitor
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - update family
   - will need to watch this weekend, and see if he improves
   - will need to discuss tracheostomy early next week, patient will have
   been intubated for 2 weeks on Monday
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NovaSource Renal (Full) - [**2100-8-13**] 04:09 AM 35 mL/hour

   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP:  VAP bundle

   Code status: DNR, cardioversion is OK
   Disposition: ICU care<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Summary:

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who was transferred to the ICU with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating rash, GBS pneumonia, and sepsis. He has been treated with antibiotics, antivirals, and vasopressors. His current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His respiratory failure is attributed to GBS pneumonia, and his current barriers to extubation include altered mental status, severe metabolic acidosis, bilateral pleural effusion, and pneumonia.
* Sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary, and the patient has been treated with antibiotics and antivirals.
* Metabolic acidosis: The patient has an anion gap acidosis, likely due to renal failure and lactic acidosis. He has been given bicarbonate to correct the acidosis.
* Renal failure: The patient has chronic kidney disease and is experiencing acute kidney injury. He has been given fluid resuscitation and is receiving renally adjusted medications.
* Skin rash: The patient has a diffuse desquamating rash, which is attributed to GBS or a hypersensitivity reaction. He is receiving treatment with clindamycin and acyclovir.
* Altered mental status: The patient has altered mental status, which is attributed to HSV encephalitis, sedation, and prolonged sepsis. He is receiving treatment with antivirals and sedatives.
* Anemia: The patient has anemia, which is attributed to GIB, anemia of chronic disease, and renal failure.
* Hyponatremia: The patient has hyponatremia, which is being monitored.
* SVT: The patient had a previous episode of SVT, which was treated with cardioversion. He is now being monitored for any future episodes.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a high-risk condition that can lead to further deterioration and even death.
* Sepsis: The patient's sepsis can lead to further organ dysfunction and death.
* Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis can lead to further organ dysfunction and death if not corrected.
* Renal failure: The patient's renal failure can lead to further organ dysfunction and death if not managed properly.
* Skin rash: The patient's skin rash can lead to further complications, such as infection and scarring.
* Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status can lead to further complications, such as decreased mobility and increased risk of falls.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia can lead to further complications, such as decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
* Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia can lead to further complications, such as seizures and coma.
* SVT: The patient's SVT can lead to further complications, such as cardiac arrest and death.

Assessment and plan:

* The patient's respiratory failure, sepsis, metabolic acidosis, and renal failure require ongoing management with antibiotics, antivirals, and vasopressors.
* The patient's skin rash requires ongoing treatment with clindamycin and acyclovir.
* The patient's altered mental status requires ongoing management with antivirals and sedatives.
* The patient's anemia requires ongoing management with blood transfusions and iron supplements.
* The patient's hyponatremia requires ongoing monitoring and correction as necessary.
* The patient's SVT requires ongoing monitoring for any future episodes.

The patient's family has requested a family meeting to discuss his care, and the patient's code status is DNR with cardioversion being acceptable. The patient's disposition is ICU care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer treatment at OSH, admitted for probable drug rash, which progressed to acute respiratory failure, sepsis, GBS pneumonia, and HSV. The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Acute respiratory failure: The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation, with a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 94%.
2. Shock: The patient has been diagnosed with septic shock, with a systolic blood pressure of 118 mmHg and a central venous pressure of 8 mmHg.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient has a creatinine level of 2.4 mg/dL, indicating AKI.
4. Altered mental status (AMS): The patient has been off sedative medications for 4 days, but his mental status remains altered.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a platelet count of 113, indicating thrombocytopenia.
6. Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT): The patient has a heart rate of 92 beats per minute.
7. Impaired skin integrity: The patient has a diffuse rash, which may be related to the HSV infection.
8. Hypernatremia: The patient has a sodium level of 141 mmol/L, indicating hypernatremia.

Potential medical complications that may arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may continue to deteriorate, requiring further interventions such as increasing oxygen support or considering extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock may worsen, leading to multi-organ failure.
3. AKI: The patient's AKI may progress to acute renal failure (ARF), requiring dialysis.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, increasing the risk of bleeding complications.
5. Skin infections: The patient's impaired skin integrity may increase the risk of skin infections, particularly with HSV.
6. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's SVT may worsen, leading to cardiac arrest or other cardiac complications.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's poor nutritional status may worsen, leading to malnutrition and other complications.

Given the patient's critical condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory values, and respiratory status, and to adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure, sepsis, and multiorgan failure. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and antibiotics for GBS pneumonia and HSV. The patient's condition has been characterized by persistent respiratory failure, shock, acidosis, and poor mental status. He has developed acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, and impaired skin integrity.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to the high RR required to ventilate, leading to further hypoxia and acidosis.
2. Shock: The patient's shock may persist or worsen, leading to further organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic kidney disease or require dialysis, further complicating his care.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may increase the risk of bleeding complications, particularly with invasive procedures or trauma.
5. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity may increase the risk of infection, particularly with invasive devices or trauma.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may lead to complications such as seizures, coma, or death if left untreated.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not treated, leading to further organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
8. Supraventricular tachycardia: The patient's supraventricular tachycardia may persist or worsen, leading to further cardiac complications.
9. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status may persist or worsen, leading to further complications such as delirium or coma.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilation and oxygenation as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's shock with vasopressors and fluids, and consider further interventions such as inotropes or vasodilators as needed.
3. Continue to manage the patient's acidosis with bicarbonate infusion and consider further interventions such as renal replacement therapy as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust treatment as needed to prevent further kidney damage.
5. Consider transfusing the patient with platelets to treat thrombocytopenia and reduce the risk of bleeding complications.
6. Consider treating the patient's hypernatremia with hypertonic saline and adjust treatment as needed to prevent further complications.
7. Consider transfusing the patient with packed red blood cells to treat anemia and improve oxygen delivery.
8. Consider treating the patient's supraventricular tachycardia with medications such as beta blockers or calcium channel blockers as needed.
9. Consider further evaluation and treatment of the patient's altered mental status, including consideration of delirium or coma, and adjust treatment as needed.

   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who was transferred from [**Hospital1 **] to [**Hospital1 1**] with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating [**Hospital1 5286**],
   found to have GBS pneumonia and sepsis and multiorgan failure (renal
   failure/resp failure/shock/acidosis).
   #) Respiratory failure:  In the context of GBS pneumonia.  Patient has
   been treated with penicillin G and clinda, and his pneumonia is
   improving on imaging.  This respiratory failure could potentially be
   secondary to generalized HSV infection, the HSV DFA and culture from
   mini-BAL are pending. The current barriers to extubation include
   altered mental status, severe metabolic acidosis, bilateral pleural
   effusion, and pneumonia which is improving.  TTE showed normal EF, r/o
   CHF. Patient's smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Pt has HSV
   infection from two sources (nasopharynx and lip).
   - on  AC currently, has increased work of breathing; Rule out autopeep
   - trial of Pressure Support in order to decrease his work of breathing
   - continue day 10 of penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the
   drug of choice for GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours
   (day1: [**8-6**]) to inhibit toxin production
   - continue day 12 of acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per
   ID this presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - continue day 8 of doxy for possible tick borne illness (day1: [**8-8**]);
   if no RMSF,  will d/c doxy
   - given bicarb (150meq in 1000cc D5W) x1 yesterday, re-check lytes in
   the pm and see if metabolic acidosis improves. If it did, consider
   giving another dose of bicarb
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u on ID recs
   - intubated x2 wks
 discuss Goals of Care for tomorrow
   .
   #) sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given his
   pneumonia.   Generalized HSV infection is another possibility but is
   less likely.  [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim was normal.  Continues to remain remain
   pressors-dependent on vasopressin and levophed.  UA was negative. Blood
   culture has been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No
   evidence of sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - treat underlying PNA.  continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8
   hours (the drug of choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to
   inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures and other infectious panel: f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma
   phagocytophilum (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Babesia
   Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella zoster
   Antibody, IgM
   - wean down pressors as pt has evidence of digital ischemia now. Goal
   MAP 55 (given his very low diastolic), although it would still be ideal
   to get his MAP to 55 to adequately perfuse his brain for improvement in
   mental status
   - with ongoing pleural effusions and nl CVP, would attempt to maintain
   MAP with pressors rather than IVF
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis: pt continues to have an anion gap, likely due to
   renal failure and lactic acidosis. Non-anion gap acidosis significantly
   improved.
   - give bicarb today, increase RR from 18 to 26  when giving bicarb
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr slowly improving.   Most likely [**12-21**] ATN from
   hypotension from sepsis.
   - support blood pressure for adequate perfusion of kidneys
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin [**Last Name (LF) 5286**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**]
   aggressively resuscitate with LR
   - renally dose medications
   .
   #) [**First Name3 (LF) **]: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin [**First Name3 (LF) 5286**]. Per derm, this is either GBS,
   generalized pustulosis (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of
   psoriasis. derm path from [**Hospital1 **]: c/w hypersensitivity reaction:
   consider drug-induced or viral etiology.  Paraneoplastic syndrome
   cannot be exluded. Less likely HSV [**Hospital1 5286**], but it it not completely
   impossible.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir per ID
   - continue triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin [**Hospital1 5286**]
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Exam revealed some stereotypical decorticate
   reflexes. Unclear whether it is HSV encephalitis. Also likely [**12-21**]
   sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   - CT head x2 were negative for any intracranial process.
   - hold off on MRI for now
   - consider LP after clarification of goals of care
   - adequate blood pressure control for better perfusion of brain (goal
   MAP 65 but it may not be a realistic goal as the diastolic pressure has
   been very low). For now, maintain goal MAP at least 55 with IVF first,
   if still low then up the pressors. Hoping bicarb will help with
   acidosis and decrease pressor requirements and help with blood
   pressure.
   - continue thiamine
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 1u pRBC on [**8-13**]. On admission Hct was
   31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic
   disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Fe studies revealed
   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No
   evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal
   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - transfuse one unit prbcs today cautiously given volume status
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct 21. Transfuse if hct <21
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient initially had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p
   free water flushes q6h which was discontinued
   -continue to monitor
   -PM lytes
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 48 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - now that levophed restarted, need to monitor
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - update family
   - will need to watch this weekend, and see if he improves
   - will need to discuss tracheostomy early next week, patient will have
   been intubated for 2 weeks on Monday

   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who was transferred from [**Hospital1 **] to [**Hospital1 1**] with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating [**Hospital1 5286**],
   found to have GBS pneumonia and sepsis and multiorgan failure (renal
   failure/resp failure/shock/acidosis).
   #) Respiratory failure:  In the context of GBS pneumonia.  Patient has
   been treated with penicillin G and clinda, and his pneumonia is
   improving on imaging.  This respiratory failure could potentially be
   secondary to generalized HSV infection, the HSV DFA and culture from
   mini-BAL are pending. The current barriers to extubation include
   altered mental status, severe metabolic acidosis, bilateral pleural
   effusion, and pneumonia which is improving.  TTE showed normal EF, r/o
   CHF. Patient's smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Pt has HSV
   infection from two sources (nasopharynx and lip).
   - on  AC currently, has increased work of breathing; Rule out autopeep
   - trial of Pressure Support in order to decrease his work of breathing
   - continue day 10 of penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the
   drug of choice for GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours
   (day1: [**8-6**]) to inhibit toxin production
   - continue day 12 of acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per
   ID this presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - continue day 8 of doxy for possible tick borne illness (day1: [**8-8**]);
   if no RMSF,  will d/c doxy
   - given bicarb (150meq in 1000cc D5W) x1 yesterday, re-check lytes in
   the pm and see if metabolic acidosis improves. If it did, consider
   giving another dose of bicarb
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u on ID recs
   - intubated x2 wks
 discuss Goals of Care for tomorrow
   .
   #) sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given his
   pneumonia.   Generalized HSV infection is another possibility but is
   less likely.  [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim was normal.  Continues to remain remain
   pressors-dependent on vasopressin and levophed.  UA was negative. Blood
   culture has been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No
   evidence of sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - treat underlying PNA.  continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8
   hours (the drug of choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to
   inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures and other infectious panel: f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma
   phagocytophilum (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Babesia
   Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella zoster
   Antibody, IgM
   - wean down pressors as pt has evidence of digital ischemia now. Goal
   MAP 55 (given his very low diastolic), although it would still be ideal
   to get his MAP to 55 to adequately perfuse his brain for improvement in
   mental status
   - with ongoing pleural effusions and nl CVP, would attempt to maintain
   MAP with pressors rather than IVF
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis: pt continues to have an anion gap, likely due to
   renal failure and lactic acidosis. Non-anion gap acidosis significantly
   improved.
   - give bicarb today, increase RR from 18 to 26  when giving bicarb
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr slowly improving.   Most likely [**12-21**] ATN from
   hypotension from sepsis.
   - support blood pressure for adequate perfusion of kidneys
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin [**Last Name (LF) 5286**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**]
   aggressively resuscitate with LR
   - renally dose medications
   .
   #) [**First Name3 (LF) **]: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin [**First Name3 (LF) 5286**]. Per derm, this is either GBS,
   generalized pustulosis (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of
   psoriasis. derm path from [**Hospital1 **]: c/w hypersensitivity reaction:
   consider drug-induced or viral etiology.  Paraneoplastic syndrome
   cannot be exluded. Less likely HSV [**Hospital1 5286**], but it it not completely
   impossible.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir per ID
   - continue triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin [**Hospital1 5286**]
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Exam revealed some stereotypical decorticate
   reflexes. Unclear whether it is HSV encephalitis. Also likely [**12-21**]
   sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   - CT head x2 were negative for any intracranial process.
   - hold off on MRI for now
   - consider LP after clarification of goals of care
   - adequate blood pressure control for better perfusion of brain (goal
   MAP 65 but it may not be a realistic goal as the diastolic pressure has
   been very low). For now, maintain goal MAP at least 55 with IVF first,
   if still low then up the pressors. Hoping bicarb will help with
   acidosis and decrease pressor requirements and help with blood
   pressure.
   - continue thiamine
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 1u pRBC on [**8-13**]. On admission Hct was
   31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic
   disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Fe studies revealed
   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No
   evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal
   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - transfuse one unit prbcs today cautiously given volume status
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct 21. Transfuse if hct <21
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient initially had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p
   free water flushes q6h which was discontinued
   -continue to monitor
   -PM lytes
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 48 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - now that levophed restarted, need to monitor
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - update family
   - will need to watch this weekend, and see if he improves
   - will need to discuss tracheostomy early next week, patient will have
   been intubated for 2 weeks on Monday

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating rash, and multiorgan failure. The patient has been diagnosed with GBS pneumonia and sepsis, and is currently intubated and pressor-dependent.

The patient's current medical conditions include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient has pneumonia and is on mechanical ventilation. The current barriers to extubation include altered mental status, severe metabolic acidosis, bilateral pleural effusion, and pneumonia.
* Sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary, and the patient is being treated with antibiotics.
* Metabolic acidosis: The patient has an anion gap acidosis, likely due to renal failure and lactic acidosis.
* Renal failure: The patient has a slow improvement in creatinine levels, and is being supported with fluid resuscitation.
* Leukoclastic vasculitis: The patient has a skin biopsy diagnosis of leukoclastic vasculitis, which may be related to toxic shock syndrome.
* Altered mental status: The patient has stereotypical decorticate reflexes, and may have HSV encephalitis.
* Anemia: The patient has a stable Hct level, and received 1 unit of PRBCs.
* Hyponatremia: The patient has been treated with free water flushes, and is being monitored.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

* Respiratory failure: Pneumonia can progress to respiratory failure, and the patient's current respiratory status is a concern.
* Sepsis: Sepsis can lead to multiorgan failure, including respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal failure.
* Metabolic acidosis: Metabolic acidosis can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, decreased cardiac output, and decreased perfusion of vital organs.
* Renal failure: Renal failure can lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and decreased clearance of waste products.
* Leukoclastic vasculitis: Leukoclastic vasculitis can lead to skin lesions, and may be related to toxic shock syndrome.
* Altered mental status: Altered mental status can lead to decreased level of consciousness, and may be related to HSV encephalitis.
* Anemia: Anemia can lead to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues, and may worsen respiratory and cardiovascular status.
* Hyponatremia: Hyponatremia can lead to seizures, coma, and death if not treated promptly.

The patient's goals of care include:

* To improve respiratory status and wean off mechanical ventilation
* To manage sepsis and underlying infections
* To improve metabolic acidosis and electrolyte imbalances
* To support renal function and prevent further decline
* To manage leukoclastic vasculitis and skin lesions
* To improve mental status and prevent further decline
* To transfuse PRBCs as needed to maintain Hct level
* To monitor and manage hyponatremia

The patient's disposition is ICU care, and the physician's plan is to continue to monitor and manage the patient's conditions, with a focus on improving respiratory status, managing sepsis and underlying infections, and supporting renal function.

   Assessment and Plan
   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who was transferred from [**Hospital1 **] to [**Hospital1 1**] with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating [**Hospital1 5286**],
   found to have GBS pneumonia and sepsis and multiorgan failure (renal
   failure/resp failure/shock/acidosis).
   #) Respiratory failure:   Has GBS pneumonia, being treated with
   penicillin G and clindamycin; pneumonia appeared to be improving on
   imaging last week but worsening again.  Possibly has component of
   generalized HSV infection-- HSV DFA and culture from mini-BAL are
   pending. The current barriers to extubation include altered mental
   status, severe metabolic acidosis, infection, hemodynamic instability.
   TTE showed normal EF, r/o CHF. Patient's smoking history puts him at
   risk for COPD.  Pt has HSV infection from two sources (nasopharynx and
   lip).
   - on  AC currently, has increased work of breathing; Rule out autopeep
   - trial of Pressure Support in order to decrease his work of breathing
   - continue day 11 of penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (for
   GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]),
   - continue clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours (day1: [**8-6**]) to inhibit
   toxin production
   - continue day 13 of acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per
   ID this presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - continue day 9 of doxy for possible tick borne illness (day1: [**8-8**]);
   if RMSF Neg,  will d/c doxy
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u on ID recs
   - intubated x2 wks
 discuss Goals of Care for tomorrow
   .
   #) Sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given his
   pneumonia.   Generalized HSV infection is another possibility but is
   less likely.  [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim was normal.  Continues on pressors--
   vasopressin and norepinephrine.  UA was negative. Blood culture has
   been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so no need for CT sinus at this time.  Consider Toxic Shock
   Syndrome, given desquamating [**Month/Year (2) 5286**]
   - continue pressors, but titrate pressors to Urine output >30ccs/hr,
   independent of MAP; continue to monitor MAP
   - treat underlying PNA.  continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8
   hours (for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures and other infectious panel: f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma
   phagocytophilum (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Babesia
   Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella zoster
   Antibody, IgM
   - because of pleural effusions and normal CVP, electing to maintain MAP
   with pressors rather than IVF
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis: pt continues to have acidosis, but appears to be
   more non-gap.  Was given bicarb previously, but bicarb is increasing
   his sodium intake, which is increasing his volume
   - d/c bicarb
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr slowly improving.   Most likely [**12-21**] ATN from
   hypotension from sepsis.
   - support blood pressure for adequate perfusion of kidneys
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin [**Last Name (LF) 5286**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**]
   aggressively resuscitate with LR
   - renally dose medications
   .
   #) [**First Name3 (LF) **]: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome.  Has new hemorrhagic bulla on hand, possibly
   indicating progression of the desquamating skin process.  Per derm,
   cefepime was d/c
d due to possibility of drug [**First Name3 (LF) 5286**] being the etiology
   of skin process.  Per derm, this is either GBS, generalized pustulosis
   (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of psoriasis. derm path from
   [**Hospital1 **]: c/w hypersensitivity reaction: consider drug-induced or viral
   etiology.  Paraneoplastic syndrome cannot be exluded. Less likely HSV
   [**Hospital1 5286**], but it it not completely impossible.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir per ID
   - continue triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin [**Hospital1 5286**]
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Had some stereotypical decorticate reflexes
   yesterday. Possibility of HSV encephalitis. Also likely [**12-21**] sedation
   and prolonged sepsis.
   - CT head x2 were negative for any intracranial process.
   - hold off on MRI for now
   - consider LP after clarification of goals of care
   - adequate blood pressure control for better perfusion of brain, but
   will titrate pressors to urine output >30ccs/hr.
   - continue thiamine
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 1u pRBC on [**8-13**] and 1 unit pRBCs [**8-15**].
   On admission Hct was 31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac
   positive, anemia of chronic disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR
   infiltrate. Fe studies revealed anemia of chronic disease/inflammation.
   B12 and folate are normal. Patient also has renal failure which also
   contributes to his anemia.
   - repeat coags and get DIC labs
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct 21. Transfuse if hct <21
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient initially had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p
   free water flushes q6h which was discontinued.  Hyponatremia 133 from
   yesterday improved to 137 yesterday evening and 136 this morning.
   -continue to monitor
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 48 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - now that levophed restarted, need to monitor
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - update family
   - will need to watch this weekend, and see if he improves
   - will need to discuss tracheostomy early next week, patient will have
   been intubated for 2 weeks on Monday

Summary:

The patient is an 84-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating rash, GBS pneumonia, sepsis, and multiorgan failure (renal failure, respiratory failure, shock, and acidosis). He has a history of throat cancer and is at risk for COPD due to his smoking history. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.9°C (98.4°F)
* Heart rate: 82 bpm (80-89)
* Blood pressure: 132/40 mmHg (105/30-137/42)
* Respiratory rate: 22 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 98%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 7 mmHg, MAP > 55 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 12.3
* Hct: 21.3
* Platelets: 136
* Creatinine: 2.6
* Glucose: 138
* Lactic acid: 1.4 mmol/L
* Albumin: 1.7 g/dL
* LDH: 182 IU/L
* Calcium: 6.8 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.6 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 4.8 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Penicillin G for GBS pneumonia
* Clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
* Acyclovir for HSV infection
* Vasopressin and norepinephrine for septic shock
* Pantoprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Heparin for DVT prophylaxis

The patient's diagnosis is:

* GBS pneumonia
* Sepsis
* Multiorgan failure (renal failure, respiratory failure, shock, and acidosis)
* Leukoclastic vasculitis
* Desquamating rash
* Possible HSV generalized infection
* Possible toxic shock syndrome

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Multiorgan failure
* Leukoclastic vasculitis
* Desquamating rash
* HSV generalized infection
* Toxic shock syndrome
* Renal failure
* Anemia
* Hyponatremia
* SVT
* Afib with RVR
* Transaminitis
* Hypothyroidism

The patient's goals of care are:

* Update family on his condition
* Monitor for improvement over the weekend
* Discuss tracheostomy early next week
* Continue to manage his septic shock and multiorgan failure
* Monitor for signs of respiratory failure and sepsis
* Continue to manage his anemia and hyponatremia
* Monitor for signs of SVT and Afib with RVR
* Continue to manage his desquamating rash and leukoclastic vasculitis
* Monitor for signs of HSV generalized infection and toxic shock syndrome

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, GBS pneumonia, sepsis, and multi-organ failure. He is currently intubated and being treated in the ICU for respiratory failure, sepsis, and metabolic acidosis. He has a desquamating skin rash, which is likely related to HSV infection, and has new hemorrhagic bullae on his hands and feet. He also has anemia, hyponatremia, and hypothyroidism. The patient's condition is unstable, and he is at risk for further complications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require further interventions, such as tracheostomy, to improve his respiratory function.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is ongoing, and he is at risk for further complications, such as organ dysfunction and death.
3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis is non-gap, and he may require further treatment to correct this condition.
4. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and he may require further interventions, such as dialysis, to manage his kidney function.
5. Skin complications: The patient's skin rash is likely related to HSV infection, and he may require further treatment, such as antiviral therapy, to manage this condition.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely related to his underlying medical conditions, and he may require further treatment, such as blood transfusions, to manage this condition.
7. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is likely related to his underlying medical conditions, and he may require further treatment, such as fluid restriction, to manage this condition.
8. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism is likely related to his underlying medical conditions, and he may require further treatment, such as thyroid hormone replacement therapy, to manage this condition.
9. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status is unstable, and he may require further interventions, such as cardioversion, to manage his cardiac rhythm.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his treatment plan as necessary.
2. Continue to manage the patient's sepsis with antibiotics and other supportive therapies.
3. Continue to treat the patient's metabolic acidosis with bicarbonate and other supportive therapies.
4. Continue to manage the patient's renal function with dialysis and other supportive therapies.
5. Continue to treat the patient's skin rash with antiviral therapy and other supportive therapies.
6. Continue to manage the patient's anemia with blood transfusions and other supportive therapies.
7. Continue to treat the patient's hyponatremia with fluid restriction and other supportive therapies.
8. Consider thyroid hormone replacement therapy for the patient's hypothyroidism.
9. Consider cardioversion for the patient's cardiac rhythm disturbances.

Summary:

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, who was transferred to the ICU with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating rash, and multiorgan failure (renal failure, respiratory failure, shock, and acidosis). He has been diagnosed with GBS pneumonia and sepsis. His current condition includes:

* Respiratory failure: treated with antibiotics and acyclovir for HSV infection
* Sepsis: likely pulmonary, with ongoing pressors-dependent vasopressin and norepinephrine
* Metabolic acidosis: anion gap likely due to renal failure and lactic acidosis
* Renal failure: Cr slowly improving, likely due to ATN from hypotension
* Leukoclastic vasculitis: diagnosed on OSH biopsy, possibly related to toxic shock syndrome
* Altered mental status: unclear whether due to HSV encephalitis, sedation, or prolonged sepsis
* Anemia: stable Hct, received 1 unit PRBC on admission, likely due to anemia of chronic disease/inflammation
* Hyponatremia: patient initially had hypernatremia, now being monitored
* SVT: resolved, likely secondary to infection, volume depletion, and levophed
* Transaminitis: resolved
* Hypothyroidism: patient started on levothyroxine, but unsure if he really has hypothyroidism or sick euthyroid syndrome

Potential medical complications:

* Pneumonia: may not be fully treated, potentially leading to further respiratory failure
* Sepsis: may lead to organ dysfunction and failure
* Metabolic acidosis: may worsen if not adequately treated
* Renal failure: may progress to end-stage renal disease if not managed properly
* Leukoclastic vasculitis: may lead to further skin damage and complications
* Altered mental status: may worsen if not treated, potentially leading to long-term cognitive impairment
* Anemia: may worsen if not managed properly, potentially leading to further complications
* Hyponatremia: may worsen if not monitored and treated properly
* SVT: may recur if not managed properly, potentially leading to further complications
* Transaminitis: may recur if not managed properly, potentially leading to liver failure
* Hypothyroidism: may worsen if not managed properly, potentially leading to further complications

Goals of care:

* Update family on patient's condition
* Monitor patient's condition over the weekend
* Discuss tracheostomy early next week, as patient will have been intubated for 2 weeks
* Continue to manage patient's respiratory, cardiac, and metabolic status
* Monitor for potential complications and adjust treatment plan as needed

Based on the provided medical progress note, I will summarize the patient's current condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating rash, GBS pneumonia, sepsis, and multi-organ failure (renal failure, respiratory failure, shock, and acidosis). He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and antibiotics.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Respiratory Failure:** The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, with worsening pneumonia and possible generalized HSV infection. He requires continued mechanical ventilation, and the possibility of extubation is uncertain.
2. **Sepsis:** The patient's sepsis is likely pulmonary in origin, but the possibility of generalized HSV infection cannot be excluded. He is receiving antibiotics, and the source of infection should be further investigated.
3. **Metabolic Acidosis:** The patient's acidosis is non-gap, and he is at risk for worsening acidosis due to continued sodium intake from bicarbonate therapy. He will require careful monitoring and adjustment of his fluid and electrolyte management.
4. **Renal Failure:** The patient's creatinine levels are slowly improving, but he remains at risk for further kidney damage due to hypotension and sepsis. He will require continued support with vasopressors and careful fluid management.
5. **Altered Mental Status:** The patient's altered mental status may be due to HSV encephalitis, sedation, or prolonged sepsis. He will require continued monitoring and consideration for LP and MRI.
6. **Anemia:** The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic disease, inflammation, or renal failure. He will require continued monitoring and transfusion if his Hct falls below 21.
7. **Hyponatremia:** The patient's hyponatremia is improving, but he will require continued monitoring to prevent worsening of his electrolyte imbalance.
8. **SVT:** The patient's SVT may be due to infection, volume depletion, or levophed therapy. He will require continued monitoring and consideration for cardioversion if he becomes hemodynamically unstable.
9. **Skin Complications:** The patient's desquamating rash may be due to GBS, generalized pustulosis, or a paraneoplastic syndrome. He will require continued monitoring and consideration for wound care and skin biopsy.
10. **Goals of Care:** The patient's goals of care should be discussed with his family, and consideration should be given to tracheostomy, withdrawal of care, and palliative care options.

In summary, the patient remains critically ill with multiple organ dysfunction, and careful monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further complications and improve his chances of survival.

Summary:

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who was transferred to the ICU with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating rash, GBS pneumonia, and sepsis. He has multi-organ failure, including renal failure, respiratory failure, shock, and acidosis. He has been treated with antibiotics, antivirals, and vasopressors. His current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.6°C (97.8°F)
* Heart rate: 82 bpm (80-89 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 132/40 mmHg (105/30 mmHg - 137/42 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute (19-26 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 98%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Pressors-dependent on vasopressin and norepinephrine

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to GBS pneumonia, but there is a possibility of generalized HSV infection.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely pulmonary, but there is also a possibility of generalized HSV infection.
3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis is likely due to renal failure and lactic acidosis.
4. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure is likely due to hypotension from sepsis.
5. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is likely due to HSV encephalitis, sedation, and prolonged sepsis.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to GIB, anemia of chronic disease/inflammation, or DAH.
7. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is likely due to free water flushes.
8. SVT: The patient's SVT is likely secondary to infection, volume depletion, and levophed.
9. Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis has resolved, but there is a possibility of recurrence.
10. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism is uncertain, and it is unclear if he has hypothyroidism or sick euthyroid syndrome.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Antibiotics: The patient is receiving antibiotics for GBS pneumonia and sepsis.
2. Antivirals: The patient is receiving antivirals for HSV infection.
3. Vasopressors: The patient is receiving vasopressors to support his blood pressure.
4. Fluid management: The patient is receiving fluids to support his blood pressure and renal function.
5. Nutrition: The patient is receiving nutritional support through a nasogastric tube.
6. Glycemic control: The patient is receiving insulin to control his blood glucose levels.
7. Prophylaxis: The patient is receiving prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and his disposition is unclear at this time.

 discuss Goals of Care for tomorrow

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's GBS pneumonia is worsening, and he is at risk of developing respiratory failure. The current barriers to extubation include altered mental status, severe metabolic acidosis, infection, and hemodynamic instability.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely pulmonary, and he is at risk of developing septic shock.
3. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's acidosis is non-gap, and he is at risk of developing more severe acidosis. The decision to discontinue bicarbonate therapy and use lactated Ringer's solution instead is appropriate.
4. Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are slowly improving, but he is at risk of developing more severe renal failure due to hypotension and sepsis.
5. Leukoclastic Vasculitis: The patient's skin biopsy shows leukoclastic vasculitis, which may be related to toxic shock syndrome.
6. HSV Encephalitis: The patient's altered mental status and stereotypical decorticate reflexes may be indicative of HSV encephalitis.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to anemia of chronic disease/inflammation, and he is at risk of developing more severe anemia.
8. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is improving, but he is at risk of developing more severe hyponatremia.
9. SVT: The patient's SVT is likely due to infection, volume depletion, or levophed, and he is at risk of developing more severe SVT.
10. Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis is resolved, but he is at risk of developing more severe liver dysfunction.
11. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism is uncertain, and he is at risk of developing more severe hypothyroidism.

The patient's goals of care include discussing tracheostomy options with the family, considering withdrawal of care, and addressing his respiratory failure, sepsis, and other complications.

   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who was transferred from [**Hospital1 **] to [**Hospital1 1**] with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating [**Hospital1 5286**],
   found to have GBS pneumonia and sepsis and multiorgan failure (renal
   failure/resp failure/shock/acidosis).
   #) Respiratory failure:   Has GBS pneumonia, being treated with
   penicillin G and clindamycin; pneumonia appeared to be improving on
   imaging last week but worsening again.  Possibly has component of
   generalized HSV infection-- HSV DFA and culture from mini-BAL are
   pending. The current barriers to extubation include altered mental
   status, severe metabolic acidosis, infection, hemodynamic instability.
   TTE showed normal EF, r/o CHF. Patient's smoking history puts him at
   risk for COPD.  Pt has HSV infection from two sources (nasopharynx and
   lip).
   - on  AC currently, has increased work of breathing; Rule out autopeep
   - trial of Pressure Support in order to decrease his work of breathing
   - continue day 11 of penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (for
   GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]),
   - continue clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours (day1: [**8-6**]) to inhibit
   toxin production
   - continue day 13 of acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per
   ID this presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - continue day 9 of doxy for possible tick borne illness (day1: [**8-8**]);
   if RMSF Neg,  will d/c doxy
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u on ID recs
   - intubated x2 wks
 discuss Goals of Care for tomorrow
   .
   #) Sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given his
   pneumonia.   Generalized HSV infection is another possibility but is
   less likely.  [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim was normal.  Continues on pressors--
   vasopressin and norepinephrine.  UA was negative. Blood culture has
   been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so no need for CT sinus at this time.  Consider Toxic Shock
   Syndrome, given desquamating [**Month/Year (2) 5286**]
   - continue pressors, but titrate pressors to Urine output >30ccs/hr,
   independent of MAP; continue to monitor MAP
   - treat underlying PNA.  continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8
   hours (for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures and other infectious panel: f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma
   phagocytophilum (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Babesia
   Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella zoster
   Antibody, IgM
   - because of pleural effusions and normal CVP, electing to maintain MAP
   with pressors rather than IVF
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis: pt continues to have acidosis, but appears to be
   more non-gap.  Was given bicarb previously, but bicarb is increasing
   his sodium intake, which is increasing his volume
   - d/c bicarb
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr slowly improving.   Most likely [**12-21**] ATN from
   hypotension from sepsis.
   - support blood pressure for adequate perfusion of kidneys
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin [**Last Name (LF) 5286**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**]
   aggressively resuscitate with LR
   - renally dose medications
   .
   #) [**First Name3 (LF) **]: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome.  Has new hemorrhagic bulla on hand, possibly
   indicating progression of the desquamating skin process.  Per derm,
   cefepime was d/c
d due to possibility of drug [**First Name3 (LF) 5286**] being the etiology
   of skin process.  Per derm, this is either GBS, generalized pustulosis
   (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of psoriasis. derm path from
   [**Hospital1 **]: c/w hypersensitivity reaction: consider drug-induced or viral
   etiology.  Paraneoplastic syndrome cannot be exluded. Less likely HSV
   [**Hospital1 5286**], but it it not completely impossible.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir per ID
   - continue triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin [**Hospital1 5286**]
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Had some stereotypical decorticate reflexes
   yesterday. Possibility of HSV encephalitis. Also likely [**12-21**] sedation
   and prolonged sepsis.
   - CT head x2 were negative for any intracranial process.
   - hold off on MRI for now
   - consider LP after clarification of goals of care
   - adequate blood pressure control for better perfusion of brain, but
   will titrate pressors to urine output >30ccs/hr.
   - continue thiamine
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 1u pRBC on [**8-13**] and 1 unit pRBCs [**8-15**].
   On admission Hct was 31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac
   positive, anemia of chronic disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR
   infiltrate. Fe studies revealed anemia of chronic disease/inflammation.
   B12 and folate are normal. Patient also has renal failure which also
   contributes to his anemia.
   - repeat coags and get DIC labs
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct 21. Transfuse if hct <21
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient initially had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p
   free water flushes q6h which was discontinued.  Hyponatremia 133 from
   yesterday improved to 137 yesterday evening and 136 this morning.
   -continue to monitor
   #) SVT:  pt was found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT with no
   recent episodes in last 3 days.  Pt was hemodynamically unstable, SBP
   in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. Differential for etiology
   of SVT includes infection, volume depletion and levophed which is a
   beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - in setting of levophed restart, need to monitor
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - family meeting tomorrow today
   - pt intubated x 2 weeks -- will need to discuss tracheostomy option
   with family in addition to goals of care and possible withdrawal of
   care
